posts.name: Aria Zadeh
posts.cooked: Are there any known teams that have publically available and up to date training for learning the basics about how to code the basics of robot specific programming in java for new members? Specifically guide’s that are not directly from the FRC website, more resources made by teams based on actual coding in java for their robots.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: Here’s my team’s basic Java lesson for operating a robot. It might not be exactly what you had in mind but it is well-received by the students compared to early years Java lessons that students thought were too dry and didn’t present the robot soon enough to keep students interested. We use Romi robots and a pair of students work together on one Romi. The students get their robots moving almost immediately. Command-Based Programming.pptx (711.2 KB)

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: docs.wpilib.org is your best bet. There’s a lot of info, but its info that you’re not gonna get anywhere else

link_counts.title: FIRST Robotics Competition Control System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
going to plug this again, lol

How To Learn FRC Programming? Programming

How To Learn FRC Programming? Programming

parts of it are still under construction, but hopefully this is helpful. if you’re specifically asking for resources for java basics, you may want to look at this page first and check out the LED project in the Exercises section
Moreso a collection of various teams resources rather then a single complete guide, but the LYNK Library of Knowledge has basically everything your looking for .

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 2508 | Co Captain, Programming Lead, Strategy Lead

posts.custom_user_title: 2508 | Co Captain, Programming Lead, Strategy Lead

posts.cooked: We are looking at using this for our programming training this year. We noticed that there have been a lot of updates to it recently and we were wondering when are you going to have it in a “done” state for this season.

I would say that currently stages 1 and 2 (General and Architecture) are largely complete. Our group of new students this year has started at a more introductory level, so we’ve had a bit more time to update as we go (though each article will of course be completed before they get to it). That being said others might be moving faster- so is there anything you’re waiting on specifically?
